doc.ContractDescription: BACKGROUND: ONE OF THE RICHEST SOURCES OF INFORMATION FOR ASTEROIDS COME FROM FAMILIES, SWARMS OF HUNDREDS TO THOUSANDS OF ASTEROIDS THAT HAVE SIMILAR ORBITS AND WERE ONCE PART OF A LARGE PARENT ASTEROID THAT WAS SUBSEQUENTLY CATASTROPHICALLY DESTROYED. EACH FAMILY IS SPECTRALLY UNIQUE, BUT THE MEMBERS WITHIN EACH FAMILY ARE SURPRISINGLY SPECTRALLY SIMILAR. FROM OXYGEN ISOTOPES, WE KNOW THAT IRON METEORITES SAMPLE THE CORES OF HEATED AND MELTED (DIFFERENTIATED) ASTEROIDS THAT HAVE BEEN SUBSEQUENTLY DISRUPTED. WE THUS EXPECT MANY OF THE PARENT ASTEROIDS OF FAMILIES TO HAVE UNDERGONE SOME LEVEL OF DIFFERENTIATION TO FORM IRON CORES, OLIVINE MANTLES AND BASALTIC CRUSTS, YET FOR DECADES WE HAVE BEEN UNSUCCESSFUL TO DETECT THESE MANTLE AND CORE FRAGMENTS THAT ENVELOPED THE IRON CORES. OF THE THOUSANDS OF OBSERVED ASTEROIDS, THERE ARE CURRENTLY ONLY A HANDFUL OF KNOWN CRUSTAL OBJECTS (ASIDE FROM THOSE BELONGING TO THE VESTA FAMILY) AND EVEN FEWER MANTLE REMNANTS. MAIN SCIENTIFIC OBJECTIVES: 1. SEARCH FOR DIFFERENTIATION REMNANTS WITHIN ASTEROID FAMILIES, INCLUDING PRIMITIVE ONES, TO FIND THE MISSING MANTLE MATERIAL AND DETERMINE WHETHER DIFFERENTIATION CAN OCCUR IN INTERIORS OF PRIMITIVE SURFACE BODIES. 2. DETERMINE THE DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE OF CRUSTAL AND MANTLE MATERIAL ACROSS THE MAIN ASTEROID BELT (MB) TO CONSTRAIN INITIAL CONDITIONS OF THE PROTOPLANETARY DISK DURING PLANETESIMAL FORMATION. STRATEGY: WE PROPOSE A "BETTER, FASTER, FAINTER" STRATEGY TO ACCOMPLISH THE SCIENTIFIC OBJECTIVES: "BETTER" BY OBTAINING NEAR-INFRARED SPECTRAL MEASUREMENTS THAT ARE MORE DIAGNOSTIC FOR COMPOSITIONAL INTERPRETATION THAN VISUAL WAVELENGTH SPECTRA. "FASTER" BY TAKING ADVANTAGE THE SLOAN DIGITAL SKY SURVEY MOVING OBJECT CATALOG TO IDENTIFY CANDIDATE DIFFERENTIATED ASTEROIDS FOR HIGHEST PRIORITY IMMEDIATE OBSERVATIONS. "FAINTER" BY EXTENDING BEYOND THE CAPABILITIES OF THE SPEX INSTRUMENT ON THE 3-METER NASA INFRARED TELESCOPE FACILITY (IRTF) BY USING A SIMILAR INSTRUMENT, FIRE, ON THE 6.5-METER MAGELLAN TELESCOPE AT LAS CAMPANAS OBSERVATORY IN CHILE; THE FAINTER MAGNITUDE LIMIT OF MAGELLAN GREATLY ENLARGES THE SAMPLE OF OBSERVABLE OBJECTS. ANALYSIS METHODS FOR THE RESULTING DATA WILL INCLUDE CLASSIFICATION WITHIN THE BUS-DEMEO TAXONOMY (DEMEO ET AL. 2009), COMPARISON WITH METEORITE SPECTRA, AND BAND CENTER AND BAND AREA RATIO CALCULATIONS. OUTCOMES AND SIGNIFICANCE: A DETECTION OF MANTLE AND CRUSTAL MATERIAL CLEARLY LINKED TO A PRIMITIVE FAMILY WOULD RADICALLY SHIFT OUR UNDERSTANDING OF PLANETESIMAL FORMATION. A DETECTION OF MANTLE MATERIAL AMONG THE CRUST-RICH VESTA FAMILY WOULD PROVIDE CONSTRAINTS ON HOW DEEP THE LARGE IMPACT EXCAVATED ON VESTA WHEN CREATING THE FAMILY, PROVIDING A COMPLEMENTARY SUPPORTING INVESTIGATION TO NASA'S DAWN MISSION. DETERMINING THE DISTRIBUTION OF MANTLE MATERIAL ACROSS THE BELT ADDRESSES THE NEWLY-RELEASED DECADAL SURVEY OBJECTIVE TO "ASSESS THE NATURE AND CHRONOLOGY OF PLANETESIMAL DIFFERENTIATION" (P. 4-3). NON-DETECTIONS WILL PROVIDE EQUALLY IMPORTANT CONSTRAINTS. FINDING A COMPLETE GEOLOGIC CROSS-SECTION (INCLUDING CRUSTAL AND MANTLE MATERIAL) WITHIN ONE SWARM (FAMILY) HAS BEEN SOUGHT FOR DECADES, BUT NEVER ACHIEVED. THE POWER OF THE SDSS SURVEY TO ZERO IN ON THE RIGHT CANDIDATES COMBINED WITH THE LIGHT-GATHERING POWER OF A 6.5-METER TELESCOPE MAY BE THE KEY TO RESOLVING THIS MYSTERY.

doc.ContractDescription: INTEREST IN SMALL-SATELLITE MISSIONS HAS GROWN RECENTLY, HOWEVER THERE HAS BEEN NO PROPULSION TECHNOLOGY CAPABLE OF SCALING DOWN TO MEET MISSION NEEDS. ELECTROSPRAY THRUSTERS HAVE THIS SCALABILITY IN THRUST, SIZE, AND MASS, BUT ACHIEVING INCREASED ELECTROSPRAY THRUST DENSITY REQUIRES MICRO- AND NANO-SCALE COMPONENT ENGINEERING. RECENT WORK HAS PRODUCED THRUSTERS OPERATING AT PROMISING LEVELS FOR NEAR-FUTURE SMALL-SATELLITE MISSIONS. IMPROVEMENTS IN PERFORMANCE MUST OCCUR AT THE LEVEL OF THE PROPELLANT EMISSION SITES WHERE PHYSICAL PROPERTIES CAN BE OPTIMIZED FOR SPECIFIC MISSION REQUIREMENTS. AN INTEGRATED MODEL OF ELECTROSPRAY EMISSION FOR PREDICTION OF PROPULSIVE PERFORMANCE WILL BE DEVELOPED AND TESTED. WITH A WORKING MODEL, VARIOUS COMBINATIONS OF THRUSTER PROPERTIES CAN BE EXAMINED TO DETERMINE CONFIGURATIONS WHICH LEAD TO DESIRED PERFORMANCE REGIMES. ADDITIONALLY, THE APPLICATION OF ELECTROSPRAY THRUSTERS TO EXAMPLE MISSION ARCHITECTURES (STATION-KEEPING, ORBITAL TRANSFER, LONG-DURATION OPERATION, ETC.) WILL BE INVESTIGATED TO DETERMINE THE IMPACT DEVELOPMENT IN THIS AREA WILL HAVE UPON FUTURE SPACE EXPLORATION.

doc.ContractDescription: WE PROPOSE TO ADDRESS FUNDAMENTAL QUESTIONS ABOUT THE MECHANISMS THAT MAINTAIN THE SURFACE SALINITY MAXIMUM OF THE NORTH ATLANTIC SUBTROPICAL GYRE USING THE DATA OBTAINED DURING THE 2012-2013 SPURS FIELD CAMPAIGN. THE PROPOSED EFFORT AIMS TO SYNTHESIZE THE MEASUREMENTS COLLECTED AND DERIVED DURING SPURS. BY COMBINING THE IN-SITU OBSERVATIONS AS WELL AS REMOTE SENSING AND MODELING PRODUCTS, THE GOALS OF THIS EFFORT ARE TO: 1) RESOLVE IMPORTANT TERMS OF THE FRESHWATER AND HEAT BUDGETS OF THE UPPER 1000 M ON TEMPORAL SCALES OF A FEW DAYS AND SPATIAL SCALES OF THE ORDER OF 100 TO 1000 KM AROUND THE SALINITY MAXIMUM. 2) IDENTIFY AND QUANTIFY THE PROCESSES RESPONSIBLE FOR THE FORMATION OF A ~100-M THICK SURFACE MIXED LAYER IN THE WINTER, FOR ITS RE- STRATIFICATION IN THE SPRING AND SUMMER AND ITS RELATIONSHIP TO THE SUB-SURFACE SALINITY MAXIMUM. THE IMPORTANCE OF LATERAL GRADIENTS IN THE TIME EVOLUTION OF THE MIXED LAYER WILL BE ASSESSED. 3) PROVIDE A DETAILED DESCRIPTION AND ANALYSIS OF THE NEAR-SURFACE (TOP 5 M) TEMPERATURE AND SALINITY FIELDS DURING A COMPLETE ANNUAL CYCLE, PAYING SPECIAL ATTENTION TO THE ROLE OF THIS NEAR-SURFACE STRUCTURE IN AIR-SEA INTERACTION AND ITS RELEVANCE TO INTERPRETATION OF SATELLITE MEASUREMENTS. THE WORK WILL INVOLVE THE ANALYSIS OF THE SHIP-BASED OBSERVATIONS FROM CRUISES THAT SUPPORTED OR WERE AFFILIATED WITH THE SPURS PROGRAM IN THE CONTEXT OF THE LONG-TERM OBSERVATIONS (MOORINGS, FLOATS, GLIDERS, DRIFTERS), AS WELL AS THE SYNTHESIS OF ALL THE FIELD OBSERVATIONS WITH THE OUTPUT OF MODELS AND SALINITY PRODUCTS FROM THE AQUARIUS/SAC-D MISSION. A DATA MANAGEMENT ELEMENT AND SPURS WORKSHOP WILL BE INCLUDED. MORE GENERALLY, THE SPURS FIELD PROGRAM AND SYNTHESIS ANALYSIS WILL MAKE ADVANCEMENTS TOWARDS THE DEVELOPMENT OF EFFECTIVE METHODS FOR THE INTEGRATION OF OBSERVATIONS FROM SATELLITES, SHIPS, AND AUTONOMOUS INSTRUMENTS. IN TURN, THE LESSONS FROM SPURS WILL HELP GUIDE THE DEVELOPMENT OF FUTURE PROGRAMS AND NUMERICAL SIMULATIONS TO IDENTIFY HOW THE OCEAN RESPONDS TO CHANGES IN THERMAL AND FRESHWATER FORCING ASSOCIATED WITH A CHANGING CLIMATE.
doc.MajorAgency: SYNTHESIS OF THE SPURS FIELD PROGRAM
doc.MajorFundingAgency: SYNTHESIS OF THE SPURS FIELD PROGRAM
